text: tempering chocolate is a process of
heating and cooling chocolate before you
use it to shape and mold if you don't
temper chocolate then as it cools you'll
get something the blooms and basic
that's white patches on your chocolate
rather than the nice shine and gloss
plus when it calls it won't fully sets
you won't get that lovely snap and it'd
be rude difficult to remove it from any
chocolate molds you're using that one
remember that different chocolates have
different melting and setting points
today I'm going to demonstrate it with
dark chocolate
when tempering chocolate you need a
little bit more to start with your
actual use at the end take a quart of it
and place it into a fridge the other 3/4
break up into a bowl the next step is to
heat your chocolate and you've got two
options either in a bowl over a pan of
gently simmering water just make sure
none of that water gets into the
chocolate chocolate and water do not mix
or in a microwave give it 30 second
glass at time stirring in between until
you get to 46 degrees Celsius next time
you need to lower that temperature of
the chocolate from 46 down to 26 degrees
Celsius and there's two ways of doing
that the traditional method would be to
pour it over marble when in fact any
cold metallic surface that's clean and
then move it around until the
temperature cools down and put it back
into the bowl alternatively if you
haven't got a marble surface like us
then remember that chocolate you put in
the fridge chop it up and use that to
seed the chocolate by putting in small
pieces of cold chocolate it will lower
the temperature down to 26 without
letting it set when you're happy the
chocolate is as low as 26 degrees you
need to raise it back up to 32 degrees
Celsius because it's dark chocolate do
that with whatever heating method you
use before either over a bain-marie or
short sharp bursts in a microwave 5 or
10 seconds at a time because if you go
above 32 too much you'll have to bring
it back down to 26 to start again and
there we go 32 degrees Celsius means
you've got beautiful glossy tempered
chocolate ready to use
once you've shaped it into whatever
shapes or molds you want you actually
don't need to store it in the fridge it
should set at room temperature unless
you're in a very hot country and if you
want a few ideas to test out your new
tempering skills then click on the eye
icon up
there it will give you plenty of
chocolate recipes sorted
